sentence: However, the conventional intravitreal injection tools are limited for implanting solid ODIs into mouse eyes due to the small eye size (about 3.2 mm diameter; 5 μL in volume) and high intraocular pressure (IOP) after injection (Figure 1).

However, the conventional intravitreal injection tools are limited for implanting solid ODIs into mouse eyes due to the small eye size (about 3.2 mm diameter; 5 μL in volume) and high intraocular pressure (IOP) after injection (Figure 1).
However, this procedure is too invasive and damaging to be applied to mouse eyes, which average only 3.2 mm in diameter (Figure 1).

Compared with the control eyes, implant-injected eyes did not show any significant structural or thickness changes in the retinal layers (Figure 3A).

We further investigated whether the procedure induced any complications by examining the hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) histology of pupil-optic nerve sections (Figure 3B) and retina sections of the eyes (Figure 3C).
Compared with the control eyes, implant-injected eyes did not show any significant structural or thickness changes in the retinal layers (Figure 3A).

We further investigated whether the procedure induced any complications by examining the hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) histology of pupil-optic nerve sections (Figure 3B) and retina sections of the eyes (Figure 3C).
The ERG responses remained stable and normal for 6 weeks post implant injection (Figure 4A).
The ERG responses remained stable and normal for 6 weeks post implant injection (Figure 4A).
Note: Final needle tip dimensions are shown in Figure 2B.

By considering the size of rodent eyes (∼3.2 mm axial length for adult mice; ∼4.6 mm axial length for adult rats; Figure 1) and the inner diameter of the needle, the implant dimensions are determined as 0.5 - 2 mm in length and 80 - 100 μm in diameter.
